awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Tuning the collective phenomena in atomically thin metals by electrostatic doping
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
Two dimensional materials are composed of layers of atoms that are only a few atoms thick. These materials, known as van der Waals (vdW) materials, have strong interactions between the atoms in the layer and weak interactions to neighboring layers.  This leads to unique electrical and optical properties which can be exploited for the next generation of electronic devices.  This project will develop new sample preparation and device fabrication techniques that will allow us to probe the unique electronic and optical properties of these materials.  This program will also provide exceptional opportunities for training of graduate students, who will gain first-hand knowledge of forefront research on 2D materials and research in a national lab through visits to the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory in Tallahassee, FL.

Technical Abstract:

Recent advances in the development of atomically thin layers of van der Waals (vdW) materials have opened up many new research opportunities. Examples include the unique electrical and optical properties of massless electrons in graphene and Berry curvature effects in monolayer semiconductor transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs). These properties are, however, mostly associated with independent particle phenomena. This project will focus on collective quantum phenomena in atomically thin TMDs and will explore the possibility of tuning the charge-density-wave (CDW) order and superconductivity in a model two-dimensional (2D) TMD metal NbSe2 by carrier density modulation through ionic liquid gating. The study will be enabled by development of new sample preparation and device fabrication methods and will be supported by combined optical and transport probes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project are to explore the possibility of effectively tuning the electronic phase transitions in atomically thin metals by electrostatic doping and to unveil the equal-spin spin triplet pairing correlation in two-dimensional (2D) non-centrosymmetric superconductors. While it is generally believed that electrostatic tuning of the physical properties of a metal is not possible because of efficient screening by the high-density free carriers, such screening is drastically weakened in 2D metals and gate tuning of electronic phase transitions becomes possible. We have successfully demonstrated the tuning of the charge-density-wave (CDW) order and superconductivity in a model 2D van der Waals? metal NbSe2 by carrier density modulation through ionic liquid gating. The study may lead to gate induced collective phases of matter to be explored in the future. In addition to gate tuning of electronic phase transitions, monolayer NbSe2 is a new non-centrosymmetric superconductor with unique Ising spin-orbit coupling (SOC), which locks the electron spin to the out-of-plane direction, i.e. effective Ising spins, and gives rise to mixed parity pairing, a superposition of even parity (spin singlet) state and odd parity (spin triplet) state. Such exotic pairing state has not been explored. We have revealed such unconventional pairing state by directly measuring the superconducting gap of 2D NbSe2 as a function of in-plane magnetic fields by tunneling spectroscopy. Our results provide strong evidence for the presence of equal-spin triplet pairing correlation in the material. The experimental demonstration of mixed-parity pairing in 2D NbSe2 will open the door for realizing topological superconductivity in 2D materials.

Understanding the pairing symmetry and control of the electronic phase transition in 2D NbSe2 are important for both a better understanding of the fundamental properties of this new non-centrosymmetric superconductor and future developments of superconducting devices based on this material. In particular, our demonstration of efficient gate control of the superconducting transitions is important for the future development of gate tunable superconducting devices. Our demonstration of an odd-parity equal-spin pairing component in 2D NbSe2 is important for realizing future superconducting spintronics devices and topological superconductivity.

In a broader perspective, non-centrosymmetric superconductivity in materials with strong spin-orbit interactions has been an important topic in the physics community. Conventional bulk superconductors with significant orbital effects under an external magnetic field has limited the access to the novel spin-dependent properties predicted for non-centrosymmetric superconductors. 2D NbSe2, with significantly quenched orbital effects, has overcome this problem and has presented a new system with unique Ising spins. Our efforts in developing techniques in understanding and controlling the basic properties of this new superconductor will lay the foundation for the future realization of novel phenomena such as equal-spin Andreev reflection, topological superconductivity, and the superconducting spin Hall and magnetoelectric effects.
